JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . She was represented by PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by PERSON , former Representative of ORG at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant lodged an action with the ORG of PERSON against her former employer , a municipal company , seeking reinstatement , the annulment of certain orders , the payment of arrears of salary , and compensation for non - pecuniary damage .

On DATE ORG accepted the case for an examination on the merits and stayed the proceedings pending the outcome of a criminal case against the company ’s director . The proceedings were resumed on DATE and a hearing was scheduled for DATE .

The applicant did not attend the hearing on DATE and the proceedings were then stayed until DATE because the judge was on leave . The applicant submitted that she had not been notified of the hearing fixed for DATE . The hearing listed for CARDINAL DATE was re - scheduled at the applicant ’s request because she was ill .

On DATE the applicant asked ORG to resume the proceedings . A hearing was scheduled for DATE . However , that hearing was adjourned because the applicant was ill . On DATE , following notification by the applicant that she was fit to participate , ORG fixed a hearing for DATE .
That hearing was not held as the applicant had requested an adjournment , claiming that she was ill . The next hearing was to take place on DATE .
Of CARDINAL hearings listed between DATE and DATE , CARDINAL were postponed because a prosecutor failed to attend , and CARDINAL was adjourned to allow the defendant to submit additional evidence .

On DATE the applicant successfully requested ORG to stay the proceedings as she was ill . The proceedings were resumed on DATE following notification by the applicant that she was able to take part in them . A hearing was scheduled for DATE . The applicant failed to appear and another hearing was scheduled for CARDINAL DATE . According to the applicant , she had not been notified of the hearing fixed for DATE .

DATE and DATE ORG stayed the proceedings CARDINAL times , at the applicant ’s request . She claimed she was not able to participate because she or her child was ill . In addition , CARDINAL hearings were postponed to provide the applicant with an opportunity to retain counsel and to enable the defendant to submit additional evidence .

According to the Government , the hearing fixed for DATE , to which the applicant had been duly summoned , was re - scheduled for DATE because she did not attend . The applicant submitted that she had not been summoned to the hearing .
No hearings were held DATE and DATE because the presiding judge was ill .
On DATE ORG disallowed the applicant ’s action because she had failed to attend the hearings on DATE and DATE and had not asked for the case to be examined in her absence .

The applicant asked ORG to quash the decision of DATE , arguing that owing to her illness she had not been able to attend the hearings on DATE and DATE , to which she , in any case , had not been summoned , and that she had not been served with a copy of the decision of DATE in due time . The proceedings were resumed on DATE and the hearing was fixed for DATE .

DATE and DATE ORG twice stayed the proceedings , acting at the applicant ’s request . The latter argued that her poor state of health prevented her from attending . In the meantime , ORG had sent a letter to the hospital treating the applicant , asking it to provide information about her health . On DATE ORG received a reply stating that the applicant ’s illness did not impair her ability to participate effectively in the proceedings .

On DATE ORG held a hearing . The applicant attended , but once again asked for an adjournment , alleging that she was not fit enough to participate effectively . ORG granted her request and stayed the proceedings .
On DATE the applicant asked ORG to resume the proceedings . The next hearing could not be held until DATE because the presiding judge was on leave .

Of CARDINAL hearings scheduled DATE and DATE , CARDINAL were adjourned at the defendant ’s request to allow for the provision of additional evidence and pending the outcome of related appeal proceedings before another court , and CARDINAL were postponed because the applicant was unfit to participate .
On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s action .

The applicant appealed . According to the applicant , she had been in hospital and had telephoned ORG to find out the date of the appeal hearing . She was informed that the appeal hearing had been scheduled for DATE . The applicant stated that she had sent a letter to ORG asking for an adjournment of the proceedings because she had been ill . The letter reached ORG on DATE .

The Government , relying on copies of ORG summonses and TIME , submitted that the applicant had been informed on CARDINAL DATE that an appeal hearing had been scheduled for DATE . Following the applicant ’s failure to attend that hearing , ORG listed a hearing for DATE and sent a letter to the applicant informing her of the date and time . On DATE ORG , in the applicant ’s absence , upheld the judgment of DATE . On DATE ORG received a request by the applicant for an adjournment of the hearing because she had been admitted to hospital . The Government provided the ORG with a copy of the applicant ’s letter showing that it had reached ORG on DATE .

In DATE the applicant instituted legal proceedings against the housing maintenance authorities and her neighbours , seeking the removal of a metal door installed in an apartment block in which she was renting a flat . On DATE ORG , at last instance , dismissed her claim .
